encodingDesc.p: TEI P5 conformant: We are coding this to compare the manuscript of the play submitted to the Lord Chamberlain’s office with the published version, using the witness encoding apparatus provided by the TEI. Page breaks recorded here are in the manuscript version. We have not indicated the change in abbreviation of character names from manuscript to print, since these seem insignificant, but rather have concentrated on recording variations in punctuation, word choice, and lineation of speeches.

editorialDecl.p: In representing Mitford’s manuscript, Mitford’s spelling and punctuation are retained, except where a word is split at the end of a line and the beginning of the next. Where Mitford’s spelling and hyphenation of words deviates from the standard, in order to facilitate searching we are using the TEI elements “choice,” “sic,” and “reg” to encode both Mitford’s spelling and the regular international standard of Oxford English spelling, following the first listed spelling in the Oxford English Dictionary. The long s and ligatured forms are not encoded.

To
WILLIAM CHARLES MACREADY, Esq.
WITH HIGH ESTEEM FOR THOSE
ENDOWMENTS WHICH HAVE CAST NEW LUSTRE ON HIS ART;
WITH WARM ADMIRATION FOR THOSE POWERS
WHICH HAVE INSPIRED,
AND THAT TASTE WHICH HAS FOSTERED, THE TRAGIC DRAMATISTS
OF HIS AGE;
WITH HEARTFELT GRATITUDE FOR THE ZEAL WITH WHICH HE
BEFRIENDED
THE PRODUCTION OF A STRANGER,
FOR THE JUDICIOUS ALTERATIONS WHICH HE SUGGESTED,
AND FOR
THE ENERGY THE PATHOS AND THE SKILL
WITH WHICH
HE MORE THAN EMBODIED ITS PRINCIPAL CHARACTER;
This Tragedy
IS MOST RESPECTFULLY DEDICATED
BY
THE AUTHOR.

The Story and Characters of the following Tragedy, are altogether fictitious. Annabel’s cautions to silence in the first Scene, and the short dialogue between her and Julian, after he awakens, will be recognised by the classical reader as borrowed from the fine opening of the Orestes of Euripedes; the incident of uncovering the body in the last Act, is also taken from the Electra of Sophocles. Of any other intentional imitation, the Author is unconscious.

She has now the pleasant task of conveying her acknowledgments to the whole of the Performers, for the zealous co-operation which has so much contributed to the success of the Play. To the talents of Miss Foote, Miss Lacy, Mr. Abbott, and Mr. Bennett, she is more especially indebted—and to Mr. Macready beyond all. That it has been honoured by the particular approbation of such a judge, and has given occasion to one of the most splendid exertions of such an Actor, will ever be the proudest distinction of Julian.
1823 Prologue to the new Tragedy of Julian

PROLOGUE,
WRITTEN BY A FRIEND.
_______
SPOKEN BY MR. CONNOR
_______

div.l: TheyThey, who in prologues for your favours ask,
Find every season more perplex their task;
Tho’Though doubts and hopes, and tremblings do not fail,
The points fall flatly, and the rhymes grow stale,
Why should the Author hint their fitting parts,
In all the pomp of verseVerse to “British Heartshearts"?
Why to such minds as yours with ardour pray,
For more than justice to a first essay?
What need to shew how absolute your power?
What stake awaits the issue of the hour,—
How hangs the scale ’twixt agony and joy,
What bliss you nourish, or what hopes destroy?—
All these you feel;—and yet we scarce can bring
A prologuePrologue to— “the posey of a Ringring"
To what may we allude? ?—Our plot untold,
Is no great chapter from the times of old;
On no august association rests,
But seeks its earliest home in kindly breasts;,—
Its scene, as inauspicious to our strain,
Is neither mournful Greece, nor kindling Spain,
But Sicily—where no defiance hurl’d
At freedom’s foes may awe the attending world.
But since old forms forbid us to submit
A Play, without a Prologue, to the Pit;
Lest this be missed by some true friend of plays,
Like the dull colleague of his earlier days;
Thus let me own how fearlessly we trust
That you will yet be mercifully just

div.l: Is not her lot intollerably hard,intolerably hard
Who does this pious office for the bardBard?
Who comes applauses not her own,to win,
ToOr pay the penance for another’s sin?
To tack, lest gentle moralizers rail,
A drawling comment to a doubtful tale;
To break with hollow mirth the sacred spell,
Which the poor poet rarely weaves too well;
Or if his sorrows haplessly are laugh’d at,
Look grave for wit to throw his closing shaft at,
Methinks our Author’s sex you shrewdly guess—
"It is a Lady’s Drama"—frankly, “Yes."
Yet, let no censure on her daring fall,
When all “life’sLife’s idle business” is—to scrawl;
Our tender bosoms learn in songsongs to melt,
And send their griefs to press—as soon as felt;
No thought in lone obscurity decays,
But dies away in neatly publish’d lays;
No tender hope can bloom and fade unseen,
It leaves its fragrance—in a magazine;
The bashful heart, whom deep emotions bless,
Hides itsit’s soft secrets in the daily press;
With hints of well-assum’d despair beguiles,
And execrates mankind to win their smiles;
A woman sure may claim no small compassion,
Who has this plea,—she’s only in the fashion.
O, if the fair’s prerogative it be,
To watch supreme o’er calumny and tea;
To slay an Author’s hopes with daintiest sneers,
And change the fates of poets, as of peers;
Regard not her unwomanly who seeks
To draw down sacred tears o’er beauty’s cheeks,
Who for her sex, by artless scenes, would keep
ItsIt’s dearest right—to weep with those that weep;
Who if, to-night her humble muse hath brought
To some sad heart a train of gentle thought,;
On some worn spirit shed that blest relief,
A generous sympathy with kindred grief,
With joy retires to life’s secluded ways,
And asks no recompense of noisier praise.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: No,; still he sleeps—! ’Twas but the myrtle bud
Tapping against the casement, as the wind
Stirred in the leafy branches. Well he loved
That pleasant bird-like sound, which, as a voice
SummonedSummon’d us forth into the fresher air
Of eve, or early morn. Ah! when again—
And yet his sleep is hopeful. For seven nights
He had not tasted slumber. Who comes here?
The gentle page! Alas! To wake him now!
Hush, Theodore! Tread softly—softlier, boy!

sp.speaker: Alfon-
sp.l: Doth he still sleep?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Speak lower.

sp.speaker: Alfon
sp.l: Doth he sleep?

sp.speaker: Annab

app.rdg: Come this way, Theodore! Here, close to me
Avoid the couch; come this way; close to me.

sp.l: He sleeps. He hath not mov’dmoved in all the hours
That thou hast been away.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Then we may hope,
Dear lady, we may hope!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Alas! Alas!
See how he lies, scarce breathing. Whilst I hung
Over his couch, I should have thought him dead,
but for his short and frequent sighs.

sp.speaker: Alfon
sp.l: Ah me!
Not even in slumber can he lose the sense
Of that deep misery. Andmisery; and I—he wakes!
Dost thou not see the quivering mantle heave
With sudden motion?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Thou hast wakened him.
Thy clamorous grief hath roused him. Hence! bBegone!

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: And yet his eyes are closed. He sleeps.
He did but move his hand.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: How changed he is!
How pale! hHow wasted! Can one little week
Of pain and sickness so have faded thee,
My princely Julian! But eight days ago
There lived not in this gladsome Sicily
So glad a spirit. Voice, and step, and eye,
All were one happiness,; till that dread hour,
When, drest in sparkling smiles, radiant and glowing,
With tender thoughts, he flew to meet the King
And his great father. He went forth alone,;
Frenzy and grief came back with him.

sp.speaker: Annab. Alf.
sp.l: And I,
Another grief.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Thou wast a comforter.
All stranger as thou art, hast thou not shared
My watch as carefully, as faithfully,
As I had been thy sister? Aye, and he

app.rdg: If ever in this wild mysterious woe
One sight or sound hath cheered him, it hath been
A glance, a word of thine.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: I never heard before
That ’twas to meet the kKing thatyon fatal night,—
Knowingly, purposely!— How could he guess
That they should meet? What moved him to that thought?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Stranger, altho’although thou be, thou can’stcanst but know
Prince Julian’s father is the regent here,
And rules for his young kinsman, King Alfonso. King Alfonso!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: WhereWherefore pity him?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: I know not; —but I am an Oorphan too.!
I interrupt thee, Llady.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Yet, in truth,
A gentle pity lingers round the name
Of King Alfonso, orphaned, as thou say’st,
And drooping into sickness, when he lost
His father—E, ever since, the mournful boy
Hath dwelt in the Villa d’Oro.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Hast thou seen him?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: The King? No— I’m of Naples. When Prince Julian
First brought me here, a bride, his royal cousin
Was fixed beside his father’s dying bed.
I never saw him,: yet I know him well,;
For I have sate, and listenedlisten’d, hour by hour,
To hear my husband speak of the fair princePrince,
And his excelling virtues.

sp.speaker: Alf.
sp.l: Did he? Ah!—Ah!--
But ’twas his wont, talking of those he loved,
To gild them with the rich, and burnishedburnish’d glow
Of his own brightness, as the evening sun
Decks all the clouds in glory.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Very dear
Was that young boy to Julian—’twas. ’Twas a friendship,
Fonder than common, blended with a kind
Protecting tenderness; such as brother
MightlyMight fitly shew unto the younger born.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Oh!, he hath proved it.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Thou dost know them both?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: I do. Say on, dear Llady.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Three weeks since,
The Duke of Melfi went to bring his ward
Here to Messina.—

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: To be crowned. They came not.
But wherefore went Prince Julian forth to meet them?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Father nor cousin came, nor Messenger; nor messenger,
From Regent or from King; and Julian chafed,
And fretted at delay. At length, a peasant,

app.rdg: No liveried groom; a slow foot-pacing serf,

sp.l: Brought tidings that the royal two, that morn
Left Villa d’Oro. Glowing from the chace,chase
Prince Julian stood, the bridle in his hand,
New lighted, soothing now his prancing steed.

app.rdg: And prattling now to me. He heard the tale,
And prattling now to me;— for I was still
So foolish fond to fly into the porch
To meet him, when I heard the quick sharp tread
Of that bright Arab, whose proud step I knew
Even as his master’s voice. He heard the tale

sp.l: And instant sprang again into his seat,

app.rdg: Wheeled round, and darted off at such a pace
As the fleet greyhound, at her speed, could scarce
Have matched. He spake no word; but as he passed,
He spake no word; but, as he passed,

sp.l: Just glanced back at me, with his gladsomedancing eyes,
And such a smile of joy, and such a wave
Of his plumed bonnet—! His return thou know’st.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: I was itshis wretched partner.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: He on foot,
Thou on the o’er travell’d horse;o’er-travelled horse, slow, yet all stained
With sweat, and panting, as if fresh escaped
From hot pursuit; and how he called for wine
For his poor Theodore, his faithful page!;
Then sate him down, and shook with the cold fit
Of anguish fever, till the strong couch rocked
Like a child’s cradle. There he sate and sighed,sigh’d;
And then the frenzy came. Theodore!

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Lady!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: He utters nought but madness; ;—yet sometimes,
Athwart his ravings, I have thought—I have feared—
Theodore, thou must know the cause?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Too well.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Oh, tell me.—

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Hush! hHe wakes!.

sp.speaker: Julian
sp.l: Sure I have slept a long, long while! Where am I?
How came I hither? Whose kind hand is this?
My Annabel!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Oh, what a happiness
To see thee gently wake from gentle sleep!
Art thou not better? Shall I raise thee up?

sp.speaker: Julian
sp.l: Aye, dearest. Have I, then been ill? I’m weak,
I trouble thee, my sweet one.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: ’Tis a joy
To minister unto thee.

sp.speaker: Julian
sp.l: Wipe my brow,.
And part these locks, that the fresh air may cool
My forehead—Feel,; feel; it burns.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Alas! how wild
This long neglect hath made thy glossy curls!,
How tangled!

sp.speaker: Julian
sp.l: I am faint. Pray, lay me down.
Surely the day is stifling

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: There.—Good boy.
Throw wide the casement. Doth not the soft breeze
Revive thee?

sp.speaker: Julian

app.rdg: I am better. I will rise. So, dear wife,
Yes. I’m better. I will rise.
Raise me again;—more upright;— So! Dear wife,

sp.l: A sick man is as wayward as a child;

app.rdg: Forgive me. I have I been long ill.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: A week.

sp.speaker: Julian
sp.l: I have no memory of aught. ’Tis just
Like waking from a dream,; a horrible
Confusion of strange miseries,; crime and blood,
And all I love.— Great hHeaven, how clear it seems!
How like a truth! I thought that I rode forth
On my white Barbary horse. —Say, did I ride
Alone that day?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Did I? Could I? No.
Thou dost mistake. I did not. Yet, ’tis strange
How plain that horror lives within my brain,
As what hath been.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Forget it.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Annabel,
I thought I was upon that gallant steed
At his full pace. Like clouds before the wind
We flew, as easily as the strong bird
That soars nearest the sun, till,; till in a pass,
Between the mountains, screams and cries forof help
Rang in mine ears, and I beheld—O heav’nGod!
It was not—could not—no! no!Could not—No. I have been sick
Of a sharp fever, and delirium shews,
And to the bodily sense makes palpable,
Unreal forms, objects of sight and sound,
Which have no being, save in the burning brain
Of the poor sufferer. Why should it shake me?!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Could’st thou walk to the window, and quaff down
The fragrant breeze, it would revive thee more
Than food or sleep. Forget these evil dreams.
Can’st thou not walk?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I’ll try.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Lean upon me,
And Theodore. Approach dear boy; support him.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Ha! art thou there? Thou? I am blinded. dazzled.Art thou here? Thou! I am blinded, dazzled!
Is this a vision?, this fair shape, that seems
A living child? Do I dream now?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: He is
Young Theodore, the. The page, who that sad night
Returned.—

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Then, all is real. Lay me down,
That I may die

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Alas! I feared too surely
That when he saw me,—

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Julian! This is grief,
Not sickness,. Julian!

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Rouse him not, dear Llady!
See how his hands are clenched!--. Waken him not
To frenzy! Oh,. Oh that I alone could bear
This weight of misery!.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: He knows the cause,
And I— It is my right, my privilege
To share thy woes, to soothe them. I’ll weep with thee,
And that will be a comfort. Did’st thou think
Thou could’st be dearer to me than before,
When thou wast well and happy? But thou art
Now. Tell me this secret. Oh, spare my heart I’ll be faithful,
I’ll never breathe a word.—Oh, Oh spare my heart
This agony of doubt! What was the horror horror
That maddened thee?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Within the rifted rocks
Of high Albano, rotting in a glen,
Dark, dark at very noon, a father lies
Murdered by his own son.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: And thou did’st see
The deed! An awefulawful sight to one so good!
Yet—

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Birds obscene, and wolf, and ravening fox,
Ere this— only the dark hairs on the ground.
And the brown crusted blood! And she can ask
Why I am mad!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Oh! a thrice awefulawful night
To one so duteous! Holy priests should lave
With blessed water that foul spot, and thou,
Pious and pitying, thou shalt—

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Hear at once,
Innocent torturer; that, drop by drop,Torturer, that drop by drop
Pour’st moultenmolten lead into my wounds, that—that glen—
Hang not upon me!—In that darksome glen
My father lies. I am a murderer!,
A parricide! Accurst of god and man!, accurst of God and man.
Let go my hand. Purest! purest and whitest saint,
Let go.!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: This is a madness. Even now
The fever shakes him.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Why, the mad are happy.!
Annabel, this is a soul-slaying truth.
There stands a witness.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Julian knew him not.
It was to save a life, a worthless life!.
Oh, that I had but died beneath the sword
Which seemed to tremble!That seemed so terrible! That I had ne’er
Been born to grieve thee, Julian! Pardon me,
Dear Llady, pardon me!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Oh, gentle boy,
How shall we soothe this grief?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Alas,! alas!
Why did he rescue me?! I’m a poor orphan;
None would have wept for me.; I had no friend
In all the world, but one.save one. I had been reared.

app.rdg: In simpleness; a quiet grave had been
A fitter home for me than the rude world;
A mossy heap, no stone, no epitaph,
Save the brief words of grief and praise (for Grief
Is still a Praiser) he perchance had spoke
When they first told him the poor boy was dead.

sp.l: Shame on me, that I shunned the sword.!

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: By heavenHeaven,
It could not be a crime to save thee! Kneelkneel
Before him, Annabel. He is the King.king

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Alfonso!?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Aye, so please you, fairest Cousin,
But still your servant. Do not hate me, lLady,
Tho’Though I have caused this misery. We have shared
One care, one fear, one hope; have watched &, have watched and wept
Together! Oh,Together. Oh how often I have longed,
As we sate silent by his restless couch,
To fall upon thy neck, and mix our fearstears,
And talk of him. I am his own poor Cousin.
Thou wilt not hate me.?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Save that lost one, who
Could hate such innocence?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: ’Twas not in hate,
But wild ambition. No ignoble sin
Dwelt in his breast. Ambition, mad ambition,
That was his iIdol. To that bloody god
He offered up the milk whitemilk-white sacrifice,
The pure, unspotted vVictim. And even then,
Even in the crime, without a breathing space
For penitence, or prayer, my sword—Alfonso,
Thou would’st have gone to hHeaven.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Art thou certain
That he is dead?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I saw him fall. The ground
Was covered with his blood.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Tell me the tale.
Did’st thou— I would not wantonly recall
That scene of anguish. —Did’st thou search his wound?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Annabel, in my eyes that scene will dwell
For ever, shutting out all lovely sights,
Even thee, my Beautiful! That torturing thought
Will burn, a living fire within my breast,
Perpetually; words can nothing add,
And nothing take away. Fear not my frenzy;
I am calm now. Thou know’st how buoyantly
I darted from the straight,thee, straight o’er vale &and hill,
Counting the miles by minutes. At the pass
Between the Albano mountains, I first breathed
A moment my hot steed, expecting still
To see the royal escort. Afar off,
As I stood, shading with my hand my eyes,
I thought I saw them; when, at once, at once I heard
From the deep glen, east of the pass, loud cries
Of mortal terror. Even in agony
I knew the voice, and darting thro’through the trees.
I saw Alfonso, prostrate on the ground,
Clinging around the knees of one, who held
A dagger over him, in act to strike,
Yet, with averted head, as if he feared
To see his innocent victim. His own face
Was hidden.; till at one spring I plunged my sword,

app.rdg: Into his side; then our eyes met, and he—
That was the mortal blow! —screamed and stretched out
His hands. Falling and dying as he was,
He half rose up, hung speechless in the air,
And looked—Oh what had been the bitterest curse
To such a look! It smote me like a sword!

sp.l: Here, here, he. He died.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: And thou—?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I could have lain
In that dark glen for ever; but there stood
The dear-bought and the deardear-bought, and the dear, kinsman and prince
And friend. We heard the far-off clang of steeds
And armed men, and fearing some new foe,
Came homeward.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: And did he, then, the unhappy,
Remain upon the ground?

sp.speaker: Julisn.
sp.l: Alas! he did.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Oh! it was but a swoon. Listen, dear Julian,
I tell thee, I have comfort.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: There is none
Left in the world. But I will listen to thee,
My fFaithfullest.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Count D’Alba sent to crave
An audience. Thou wast sleeping. I refused
To see him; but his messenger revealed
To Constance his high tidings, which she poured
In my unwilling ears;, for I so feared
To wake thee, that ere half her tale was told
I chid her from me. Yet; yet she surely said
The Duke, thy father—

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Approached the city.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Alive? Alive? Oh! no!Oh no! no! no! Dead! Dead!
The corse! the clay cold, the clay-cold corse!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Alive, I think;
But Constance—
He will sink under this shock
Of hope.

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: Constance heard all.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Constance! What ho!,
Constance!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: She hears thee not.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Go seek her,—fly! Fly!
If he’s alive, why—Why art thou not returned?,
When that one little word will save two souls?!

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Take patience, dearest cousin.Cousin!

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Do I not stand
Here, like a man of marble? Do I stir?
She creeps; she creeps. Thou would’st have gone and back
In half the time.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Nay, nay, ’tis scarce a minute.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Thou may’st count hours and ages on my heart.—
Is she not coming?

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Shall I seek her?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Hark!
They’ve met. There are two steps; two silken gowns
Rustling,; one whispering voice. Annabel! Constance!.
Is he—one word!—Only one word!

sp.speaker: Annab.
sp.l: He lives!.

app.rdg: Julian sinks on his knees before the couch. Alfonso & Annabel go to him. Scene drops.
Julian sinks on his knees before the couch; Alfonso and Annabel go to him, and the scene falls.

div.head: Scene 1
div.stage: A splendid Hall of Audience in the Royal Palace.royal Palace, magnificently decorated.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Again refuse to see me!

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Nay, my lord,
She’s still beside her husband’s couch, and Paolo
Refused to bear the message.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Even her lacquey
Reads my hot love, and her contempt!. No matter.!
How’s Julian?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Mending fast.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: He’ll live! He’ll live!
She watches over him, making an air
With her sweet breath. He’llbreath;—he’ll be immortal! Yet
If that dark tale be true, or half. —or half—Bertone,
Haste to the court of guard. SeekCourt of Guard; seek Juan Castro,
A Spanish soldier. Lead; lead him home. I’ll join ye.
Hence! I expect the Barons, whom I summoned
To meet me here. Come back!. See if the Princess
Will now admit me. No!—’Twould ’twould wake suspicion.
Hence to the Court of Guard!
I think that scorn
Doth fan love more than beauty. Twice to-day
Have I paced patiently these royal halls,
Like some expecting needy courtier. Swell not,
Proud charmer, thy vast debt! Where lag these Barons?
Methinks this change might rouse—
sp.stage: Enter Calvi, followed by other LordsNobles.

sp.speaker: Calvi.
sp.l: A fair good morrow, D’Alba.!

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Hast thou heard
These heavy tidings? The young king.King—

app.rdg: Meeting the other lords, as they drop in
Approaching to meet the other Lords as they enter.

sp.l: My Lords,
Good morrow’s out of date!. Know ye the news?

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Murdered!.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.

app.rdg: Giving a Letter Aye, here’s a letter from the great regent.—
Aye, here’s a letter.giving a letter to Calvi.
From the great Regent—Pshaw! how my rude tongue

sp.l: Stumbles at these new dignities! The!--the King.
Therefore I summoned ye. He will be here
Anon.
Valore, thou art late.

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: This tale
Puts lead into men’s heels. How fell it?

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Read,!
Count Calvi! Read!

sp.speaker: Calvi.
sp.p: Alfonso being dead, and I hurt almost to death, they left me fainting on the ground, where I lay, till a poor, but honest, muleteer bore me to his hut.—-
sp.l: He hath been wounded!

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Only the pretty boy! Read on. Read on!.

p.quote:
Make known these missives to our loyal people. We shall follow them straight. From your loving cousin,
"The King.""The King."

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: The King. How he will wear his state!How proudly he will wear his state. Why, D’Alba,
Thy worshipped Annabel chose well. She’ll; she’ll be
A Queen.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Yet, my poor title, had she graced it,
Comes by unquestionedunquestion’d sheer descent, unstainedunstain’d
By dark, mysterious murder. My good Fathers,fathers—
Heaven rest their souls! lie—lie safely in the churchyard,
A simple race! Whilst; whilst these high pPrinces—Sirs,
These palace walls have echoes, or I’d tell ye,—
’Tis a deep riddle—, but amongst them all
The pretty boy is dead.
Leanti!

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: Lords,
The King is at the gate.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: The King! Now, Sirs,
Don your quick smiles, and bend your supple knees.;—
The King!
He’s pale,—he, he hath been hurt.aloud My liege,
Your vassals bid you welcome.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Noble Signors,
I greet you well. Thanks, D’Alba. Good Leanti
I joy to see those reverend locks. I never
Thought to behold a friendly face again.
And now I bring ye sorrow. Death hath been
Too busy, tho’; though the ripe and bearded ear
EscapedEscap’d his sickle—but ye know the tale;
Ye welcomed me as King,; and I am spared
The painful repetition.

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: Sire, we know,
From your own royal hand enough for joy
And sorrow. Death hath ta’en a goodly boy,child
And spared a glorious man. But how—

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: My lord,
What wouldst thou more? Before I entered here,
Messina’s general voice had hailed her Sovereign,.
Lacks but the ceremonial form. ’Twere best
Th’The accustomed pageant were performed even now,
Whilst ye, Sicilian Barons, strength &and grace
Of our Sicilian realm, are here to pledge
Solemn allegiance. Say I sooth, Count D’Alba?

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: In sooth my liege, I know not. Seems to me
One form is wanting. Our bereaved state
Stands like a widow, one eye dropping tears,
For her lost lord, the other turned with smiles
On her new bridegroom. But even she, the Dame
Of Ephesus, the buxom relict, famed
For quick dispatch o’er every widowed mate,
Woman or state, —even she, before she wed,
Saw the good man entombed. The funeral first,Funeral first;
And then the coronation!Coronation.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Scoffer! Lords,
The corse is missing.

sp.speaker: Calvi.
sp.l: Ha! perchance he lives.Perchance he lives?

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: He fell, I tell thee.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: He! Why, my liege,
Was there but one?

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: What mean ye, Sirs? Stand off!.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Cannot your Highness guess the murderer?

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Stand from about me, Lords! Dare ye to front
A King? What d’yedo ye doubt me,; you, or you?
Dare ye to doubt me? Dare ye look a question
Into mine eyes? Take thy gaze off! A kingKing
Demands a modester regard. Now, Sirs,
What do ye seek? I tell ye, the fair boy
Fell underneath the Assassin’s sword,assassin’s sword; and I,
Wounded almost to death, am saved to prove
My subjects’ faith, to punish, to reward,
To reign, I tell ye, nobles. Now, who questions?
Who glares upon me now? What,What! are ye mute?

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: Deign to receive our homage, Sire, and pardon
The undesigned offence. Your highnessHighness knows
Count D’Alba’s mood.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: And he knows mine. Well! Well!
Be all these heats forgotten.

app.rdg: A pause, during which, Melfi looks round the circle

sp.speaker: Calvi.
sp.l: How his eye
Wanders around the circle!.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Ye are met,
Barons of Sicily, in such august
And full assemblage, as may well beseem
Your office;, honour well yourselves and me;
Yet one is missing,—greatest, first and best,—
My son. Knows not Prince Julian, that his father
Is here? Will he not come? Go, some one say
That I would see him.

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: Sire, the Prince hath lain
Sick of a desperate malady.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Alas!
And I—sick, did’stSick didst thou say?

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: Eight days have passed
Since he hath left his couch.

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: He’s better now.
The gentle princess, who,Princess, who with one young page
Hath tended him—

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: What page?

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: A stranger boy,
Seen but of few, young Theodore.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: A stranger!
Say on. The princess—Princess—?

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: As I crossed the hall,
I met her, with her own glad step, her look
Of joy, and when I asked how fared prince Julian,; and when I asked how fared Prince Julian?
She put her white hands into mine, with such
A smile, and then passed on—.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Without a word?

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: Without a word, save the mute eloquence
Of that bright smile.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Smile on that dotard! Whilst I. —aloud Why, my lords,
Here’s a fine natural sympathy,; the son
Sickens at the father’s wound! The very day,—!
The very hour.! He must have known the deed;—
Perchance, he knows the Assassin.assassin—

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Stop!.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: My liege,
I speak it in his honorhonour. Many an heir
Had been right glad to step into a throne
Just as the mounting pulse of youth beat high.;—
A soldier, too! Andand with a bride so fair,
So delicate, so fashioned for a Queen
By cunning nature. But he—for full surely
He knew—

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Stop—no, no, no—Stop. No, no, no, he knew it not!
He is my son!.

sp.speaker: Calvi.
sp.l: My liege, the Prince,—!

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Already!
Pardon me, good my lords, that I request
A moment’s loneliness. We have been near
To death since last—Have touched upon the grave—,
And there are thoughts, which only our own hearts
Should hear. I pray ye, pardon me. I’ll join ye
Within the hour for the procession.
Julian!

app.rdg: Approach! Come nearer! Speak to me!
Has he forgot to call me father?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Father!

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: I know what thou would’st say.. The hat

app.rdg: And sable plumes concealed—No more of it.
What would’st thou? Thou didst summon me.
Rise, my son. Let us forget
What—How is Annabel? They say she has been
A faithful nurse. Thou hast been sick?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I’m well.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Fie! when thou shakesttremblest so.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I’m well. Call not these thoughts again—I have been
Sick, brainsick, heartsick, mad! But that is past!. I thought—I feared—
It was a foretaste of the pains of hHell
To be so mad, and yet retain the sense
Of that, which made me so. But all is past,But thou art here,

app.rdg: Is it not, father? Ne’er to live again,
And I—Oh nothing but a father’s heart
Even in a dream. Is it not past?

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Thou hast not told me of thy wife. They say.

app.rdg: She has been a constant nurse to thee.

sp.speaker: Julian.

app.rdg: She, and one other—Oh that I might tell
The story of their goodness! She attends

sp.l: To pay her duty..

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Stay!. Count D’Alba looked
With evil eyes upon thee, and on me
Cast his accustomed tauntings. Is there aught
Amiss between ye?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: He hath not yet
Perhaps forgotten your long rivalry
For Annabel’s fair hand. A dangerous meaning
Lived in those bitter gibes; aLurked in those bitter gibes. A dangerous foe
Were D’Alba. Julian, the sea-breezesea breeze to thee
Brings health and strengthhealth, and strength, and joy. I have an errand
As far as Madrid. None so well as thou
Can bid it speed. There shalt away to-day.to day;—

app.rdg: Tis thy best medicine—Thou and thy young wife—
’Tis thy best medicine;—thou and thy young wife.

sp.l: The wind is fair.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Have I not said?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Send me, just risen from a sick couch, just risen from a sick couch to Madrid!
LeadSend me from home, from thee! Banish me! Father,
Can’st thou not bear my sight?

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: I cannot bear
Contention. Must I needs remind thee, Julian,
I have also been ill?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I’ll go to-dayto day.
How pale he is.! I had not dared before
To look upon his face. I’ll go to-dayto day.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: This very hour?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: This very hour.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: My son,!
Now call thy—Yet a moment—Where’s the boy?yet a moment. Where’s the boy—
He shall aboard with thee—thy pretty page!?

app.rdg: The king! Mean’st thou the king?
The King? Mean’st thou the King?

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: He, whom thou call’st—

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Wilt thou not say the kKing?

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Young Theodore.

app.rdg: Harken, prince Julian. I am glad, right glad,
Hearken, Prince Julian! I am glad, right glad

sp.l: Of what hath chanced. ’Twas well to bring him hither,
And keep him at thy side. He shall away
To Spain with thee, that Theodore—Forget
All other titles. He’ll be glad of this.

app.rdg: A favorite page, a spoilt & petted boy
A favourite page, a spoilt and petted boy,

sp.l: To lie in summer gardens, in the shade
Of orange groves, whose pearly blossoms fall
Amidst his clustering curls, and to his lute
Sing tenderest ditties—such his happy lot.,—such his happy lot;
Whilst I—go,Go, bring thy wife.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: He is the kKing.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Call lady Annabel.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: The king, I say!King, I say,
The rightful king! The only king!King, the only King! I’ll shed
The last drop in my veins for king Alfonso!King Alfonso.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Once I forgave thee. But to beard me thus,
And for a weak, and peevish youth, a faintling,
A boy of a girl’s temper,; one who shrinks
Trembling and crouching at a look, a word,
A lifted finger, like a beaten hound!.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Alas! poor boy,! he hath no other friend,
Since thou, who should’st defend him,—Father! Father!Father, Father,
Three months have scarcely passed since thy dear brother,
(Oh, surely thou loved’st him!) with the last words
He ever spake, besought thy guardian care
Of his fair child. Next upon me he turned,
His dying eyes, quite speechless then, and thou,—
I could not speak, for poor Alfonso threw
Himself upon my breast, with such a gustgush
Of natural grief, I had no utterance—
But thou didst vow for both protection, faith,
Allegiance; thou did’st swear so fervently,
So deeply, that the Spirit flew to heavenspirit flew to Heaven
Smiling—. I’ll keep that oath.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Urge not that thought uponon me. ’Tis a fire
Here in my heart; my brain. Bethink thee, father,, my brain. Bethink thee, Father,
Soldier, StatesmanSoldier or statesman, thine is the first name
Of Sicily, the General, Regent, Prince,

app.rdg: The unmatched in power, the unapproached in fame,—
The unmatch’d in power, the unapproach’d in fame;

sp.l: What could that little word a kKing do more
For thee?

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: That little word! Why thatthat is fame,
And power, and glory! That shall fill the world,
Lend a whole age its name, and float along
The Stream of Timestream of time, with such a buoyancy,
As shall endure when palaces and tombs
Are swept away like dust. That little word!
Beshrew thy womanish heart, that cannot feel
Its spell!

app.rdg: Guns and shouts are heard without.

sp.l: Hark! Hark! The Guns! I feel it nowguns! I feel it now.
I am proclaimed. Before I entered here,
’Twas known throughout the Citycity that I lived,
And the boy-king was dead. Hark! King Rugiero.
Dost hear the bells, the shouts? Oh, ’tis a proud,
And glorious feeling thus at once to live
Within a thousand bounding hearts, to hear
The strong out-gushing of that present fame,
For whose uncertain dim futurity
Men toil, and slay, and die! Without a crime—
I thank thee still for that—without a crime,—Without a crime—
For he’ll be happier,—I am a king!—I am a King.
Dost thou not hear, Long live the King, Rugeiro! Long live the King Rugiero?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: The shout is weak.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Augment it by thy voice.
Would the words choake Prince Julian? Cannot he
Wish long life to his fFather?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Live, my fFather!
Long live the Duke of Melfi!

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Live the King!

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Long live the king,King Alfonso!

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Now, by hHeaven,
Thou art still brainsick. There is a contagion
In the soft dreamy nature of that child,
That thou, a soldier—I was over proudoverproud
Of thee, and thy young fame, that. That lofty brow
Seemed madeSeem’d form’d to wear a crown. Chiefly for thee—
Where is the pPage?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Oh fFather, once again
Take pity on us all! For me! For me!
Thou hast always been to me the kindest, fondest,—
Preventing all my wishes— I’ll not reason,
I’ll not contend with thee. Here at thy feet,
Prostrate in spirit, as in form, I cry
For mercy! Save me from despair,! from sin!

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Unmanly, rise! Llest in that slavish posture
I treat thee as a slave.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Thy words strike deeper, to the very core.pierce deeper, to the very core!

app.rdg: Smite an thou wilt, but hear me. Oh my father,
Strike an thou wilt; but hear me. Oh my Father,

sp.l: I do conjure thee, by that name, by all
The boundless love it guerdons, spare my soul
This bitterness.!

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: I’ll reign.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Aye, reign, indeed!reign indeed;

app.rdg: Reign over mightier realms! Be conqueror
Rule over mightier realms; be conqueror
Of crowned passions! King of thy own mind!
Of crowned passions; king of thy own mind.

sp.l: I’ve ever loved thee as a son,—Do this,, do this
And I shall worship thee. I will cling to thee!;
Thou shalt not shake me off!.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Go to—Thou’rt mad!; thou art mad.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Not yet; but thou may’st make me so.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: I’ll make thee
The heir of a fair crown.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Not all the powers
Of all the earth can force upon my brow
That heritage of guilt. Cannot I die?
But that were happiness! I’d make theerather drag. I’d rather drag
A weary life, beneath the silent rule
Of the stern Trappist, digging my own grave;,
Myself a living corse, cut off from the sweet,
And natural kindness that man shews to man,;
I’d rather hang, a hermit, on the steep

app.rdg: Of horrid Ætna, between snow and fire,
Of horrid Etna, between snow and fire;

sp.l: Rather than sit, a crowned and honoured prince,a crown’d and honour’d prince
Guarded by children, tributaries, friends,
On an Uusurper’s throne.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: I must away.
We’ll talk of this anon. Where is the boy?.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Safe.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Trifle not with my impatience, Julian.;
Produce the child. HoweverHowe’er thou may deny
Allegiance to the king, obey thy father.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I had a father.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Ha!

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: But he gave up
Faith, loyalty, & honorand honour, and pure fame,
And his own son.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: My son!

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I loved him once,
And dearly. Still too dearly! But with all
That burning, aching, passionate old love
Wrestling within my breast, even face to face,; even face to face;
Those eyes upon me,; and that trembling hand
Thrilling my very heartstrings—Take it off,!
In mercy, take it off! Still I renounce thee,!--Still I renounce thee.
Thou hast no son—IThou hast no son. I have no father. Go
Down to a childless grave.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Even from the grave
A father’s curse may reach thee, clinging to thee,
Cold as a dead man’s shroud, shadowing thy days,
Haunting thy dreams, and hanging, a thick cloud,
’Twixt thee and heaven. Then when,Heaven. Then, when perchance thine own
Small prattling pretty ones shall climb thy knee,
And bid thee bless them, think of thy dead father,
And groan, as thou dost now.
Hark! ’tis the hour!
I must away. Back to thy chamber, son,
And chuse if I shall curse thee.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Did he curse me?
Did he? Am I that withered, blasted wretch?
Is that the fire that burns my brain? not yet,—Not yet!
Oh, do not curse me yet—yet! He’s gone. The boy!
The boy!

A Magnificent Cathedral. A Gothic Monument in the Foreground, with Steps round it, and the Figure of an old Warrior on the top.

div.stage: D’Alba, Leanti, Valore, Calvi, and other nobles.

sp.speaker: Calvi.
sp.l: Where stays the kKing?

sp.speaker: Leanti
sp.l: He’s robing, to assume
The Crown.

sp.speaker: Calvi.
sp.l: What a gloom reigns in the Cathedral!
Where are the people, who should make and grace
This pageant?

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: ’Tis too sudden.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Saw ye not
How coldly, as the slow procession moved,
Men’s eyes were fixed upon him? Silently
We passed amid dull silence. I could hear
The chink of money, which the Hheralds flung,
Reverberate on the pavement. They, who stooped
To gather up the coin, looked on the impress
Of young Alfonso, sighed, and shook their heads
As ’twere his funeral.

sp.speaker: Calvi.
sp.l: Methinks this place,
The general tomb of his high like,line doth cry
Shame on us! The mute citizens do mourn him
Better than we.

sp.speaker: D’Alba
sp.l: Therefore the gates are closed,
And none but peers of Sicily may pass
The guarded doors..

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: Where is Prince Julian?

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Sick.
Here comes the mighty-one, and the great prelates,Mighty One, and the great Prelates
That shall anoint his haughty brow; ’tis bent
With a stern joy..

app.rdg: Enter Nobles, Bishops, Abbots &c. in procession. An Abbot, bearing the crown, and lastly Melfi, in royal robes.
Enter Melfi, in Royal Robes, preceded by Nobles, Officers, &c. bearing the Crown, Archbishop, Bishops, &c.

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: No! To no tapered shrine.! Here! This is my Altar;

app.rdg: Here, reverend Fathers, here! This is my altar:

sp.l: The tomb of my great ancestor, who first
Won from the Paynim this Sicilian crown,
And wore it gloriously; whose name I bear,
As I will bear his honouredhonour’d sceptre. Here,
At this most kingly Aaltar, will I plight
My vow to Sicily, the nuptial vow
That links my fate to her’s. Here I’ll receive
Her Barons’ answering faith. Hear me, thou shade
Of great Rugiero, whilst I swear to guard,
With heart and hand, the realm thy valour won,
The laws thy wisdom framed—brave legacy
To prince and people! to defend their rights;,
To rule in truth and justice, peacefully,
If peace may be; and with the aweful arm
Of lawful power to sweep the oppressor off
From thy blest Isle; to be the peasants’ king,—Peasants’ King—
Nobles, hear that!--the peasant’s king and yours’Peasants’ King and yours!
Look down, ancestral spiritAncestral Spirit, on my oath,
And sanctify and bless it! Now the crown.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: What noise is that at the gate?

app.rdg: ’Tis fallen! Save us from the ill omen!
From thy dull hands, old dotard! Thou a Priest,
And tremble at the touch of power! Give me

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Give me the crown,
And with a steady grasp it shall endue
These throbbing brows, that burn till they are bound
With that bright diadem.

app.rdg: Enter Julian quickly hurrying Alfonso along.

sp.speaker: Julian
sp.l: This is the King,! the real, the only King!
The living King Alfonso!

sp.speaker: Melfi.
sp.l: Out, foul traitor!

And must I—? But?—But I fear not. I’ll go with thee.
I’m safe of foot, and light—. I’ll go.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Thou can’st not.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Then go thyself, or he will find thee here,
He, and his ruffian band— and his ruffian band. Let us part now.
Kiss me again!--. Fly, fly from Sicily!—
That fearful man! But he is all one lie,—but he is all one lie—
Told me thy life was forfeited.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: He told thee
A truth.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: My Annabel,
The bloodhounds that he laid upon the scent
Have tracked me hither.—Did’st. Didst thou hear a gun?
For once the ball passed harmless.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Art thou hurt?
Art sure thou art not?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Yes, but. But they who aimed
That death, are on the watch—. Their quarry’s lodged.
We can escape them—one way—only one way.one!

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: How? What way?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Ask not.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Whither?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: ToTo—my father.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Then he’s alive!--Oh,—Oh happiness! They told me
That he was dead.—. Why do we loiter here?
Let’s join him now.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Not yet.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Now,! now! Thou know’st not
How horribly these walls do picture to me
The several agonies whereof my soul
Hath drunk to-day.—Ito day. I have been tempted, Julian,
By one—a fiend!—Tempted ’till tempted till I almost thought

Do crowd around me with a visible weight,

sp.l: Annabel, look forth
Upon this glorious world! Look once again
On our fair Sicily, lit by that sun,
Whose level beams do cast a golden shine
On sea, and shore, and city, on the pride
Of bowery groves, on Etna’s smouldering top!; on Etna’s smouldering top;—
Oh, bright and glorious world! Aand thou of all
Created things most glorious, tricked in light,
As the stars that live in Heaven!

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Why dost thou gaze
So sadly on me?.

sp.speaker: Julian.

High mysteries!--and thou didst wish thyself

Can’st thou? Thou cam’st to save—

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Oh, no! no! Live! Live!live! live!
If I must die—Oh, it is sweet to live,
To breathe, to move, to feel the throbbing blood,
Beat in the veins, ,—to look on such an earth,
On such a Heaven, ,—to look on thee! Young life
Is very dear!.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: Would’st live for D’Alba?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: No.!
I had forgot.—I’ll die.—Quick! quick!. I’ll die. Quick! Quick!

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: One kiss!
Angel, dost thou forgive me?

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: My sword,!—
I cannot draw it.

sp.speaker: Anna.
sp.l: Now!--I’m ready!! I’m ready.

Yield thee, Prince Julian!--Yield thee! Seize the lady!! Yield thee! Seize the lady.

Stand off! I’ll guard thee, sweet. But, but when I fall
Let him not triumph.

sp.speaker: Bertone.
sp.l: Yield thee!
Strike him down! Now!.

Death’s factor? Peopler of unhallowed graves?, peopler of unhallowed graves,

Till I’ve avenged thee!--; I could slay an army
Now, in my strong despair.—But that were mercy.—. But that were mercy.

sp.l: Who slew him?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I.

sp.l: And the Ladylady,—where is she?

sp.speaker: Julian.

Gloat with hot love upon that beauteous dust!—
She’s safe! She’s dead!

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Julian!

sp.l: But touch her not!
She’s mine.

sp.speaker: D’Alba.
sp.l: Oh, perfectest and loveliest thing!
Eternal curses rest upon his head
Who murdered thee!

She’s white! she’s pure!--Curses! Pour curse for curseShe’s pure!--Curses! Now curse for curse
On the foul murderer, on! On him who turned
The sweet soul from her home, who slew her father,
Hunted her husband as a beast of prey,
Pursued, imprisoned, lusted, left no gate
Open, save that to Heaven!—Off! gaze not on her!
Thy look is profanation!

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: This way!—Oh, Oh sight of horror! Julian! Julian!

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: The Princess dead!—Why, Why D’Alba—

Lead him before the States.—. This bloody scene

OfOf a world that sweats under a load of fools,—

Lords, I’d defy ye! I’d live on for ever!

The glorious vision!--Aand the Patriarch’s years

Ye cannot call back her.

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: Off with him!

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Julian! Wilt thou not speak?

sp.speaker: Julian.
sp.l: I have been thanking Hheaven
That she is dead.

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: His wits are gone.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: My Julian,
Look on me.—. Dost thou know me? I’m thy Cousin,
Thy comforter!.

I’m glad thou’rt come to close my eyes.—Draw nearer, Draw nearer

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: Here!

Bury us in one grave,—all in one grave!
I did not kill her—Strew her with white flowers,
For she was innocent!.

sp.speaker: Leanti.
sp.l: Cheer thee! Take hope!

sp.speaker: Valore.
sp.l: Raise up his head!.

sp.speaker: Alfon.
sp.l: My Julian!
